content: MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS WILDERNESS AND ERNEST F. COE VISITOR CENTER in Everglades National Park. Marjory Stoneman Douglas, known for defining the Everglades ecosystem through her book "The Everglades: River of Grass," dedicated her life to its preservation. As the last surviving member of the original group that established Everglades National Park, she fought against threats to the water supply and ecology, inspiring others to take action. Ernest F. Coe, recognized as the "Father of Everglades National Park," was a leader in its creation and preservation. His vision as a landscape architect aimed to protect south Florida's diverse wildlife and habitats for future generations. He organized the Tropic Everglades National Park Association and his efforts led to the establishment of Everglades National Park, Big Cypress National Preserve, and the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary. Ernest F. Coe's leadership and commitment led to the authorization of Everglades National Park in 1934. He fought tirelessly for its establishment, realizing his dream in 1947. His selfless devotion and personal expense demonstrated his dedication to the park's creation. The purpose of this section is to honor Coe and Marjory Stoneman Douglas for their contributions to protecting the Everglades and establishing the park. The Everglades Wilderness Act of 1978 is amended to rename it the Marjory Stoneman Douglas Wilderness in honor of her vision and leadership in protecting the Everglades and establishing Everglades National Park. The Secretary of the Interior will notify the public of this redesignation through various means. The Everglades Wilderness Act of 1978 is amended to rename it the Marjory Stoneman Douglas Wilderness. The Ernest F. Coe Visitor Center will be designated as such upon completion of construction. The Ernest F. Coe Visitor Center will be renamed the Marjory Stoneman Douglas Visitor Center. Additionally, a technical correction will be made to the wording in subsection (c)(2) of the Everglades Wilderness Act of 1978.
